Conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to value-added chemicals is achieving increased attention from an environmental and industrial perspective because it could reduce the dependency on petroleum as raw material and also its net emission into the atmosphere. We present mechanisms for the CO2 hydrogenation on the aluminum-based metal-organic framework DUT-5 support transition metal(II)-hydride in a detailed using density functional (DFT) calculations. Two different pathways, namely, Eley-Rideal (ER) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanisms are described. The ER mechanism requires activation barriers of 8.5 and 15.1 kcal/mol for the formation of formate and of formic acid steps, respectively. The first barrier is three times lower than in the LH mechanism (27.4 kcal/mol), thus favouring the ER mechanism. Supported DUT-5 MOFs are also found to have a stabilizing effect on the intermediates and transition states formed along the reaction coordinate. Finally, we screen the catalytic activities of different metals substituted into MH-DUT-5 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) MOFs for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid. It is found that NiH-DUT-5 exhibits the highest catalytic activity, based on its barriers. It can stay in the atmosphere for hundreds of years. Carbon dioxide emissions mainly come from the decomposition of organic materials and from burning coal, oil, gas, wood, and solid waste. Transforming CO2 into value-added substances has fascinated chemists ever so. The challenge of CO2 conversion are related to both its kinetic and thermodynamic stability and the utilization of effective catalysts has been proposed to overcome at least the first challenge. Among the possible target products, formic acid (HCOOH) is one of the most interesting because of its numerous applications in food and textile industry and others. Several methods have been developed for transforming CO2 into formic acid such as electrocatalytic reduction [1–8] and hydrogenation [9,10]. The latter is an attractive venue and amongst various catalysts, particularly transition-metal complexes [10–17] facilitate the hydrogenation of CO2 to form formic acid. Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) [18] are a class of compounds consisting of metal ions or clusters coordinated to organic ligands to form one-, two-, or three-dimensional structures. Their high surface area, tuneable porosity and the diversity of both metal and functional groups make them attractive both as catalysts [19–24] and to store and capture gasses such as CO2 and H2 [25–31]. MOFs provide thermally and chemically robust solid platforms to host site-isolated catalytically active species [32–36]. MOF-supported single-atom catalysts can combine the advantages of homogeneous catalysts such as homogeneity of the active sites, reproducibility, and selectivity and those of heterogeneous counter parts such as excellent robustness and easy recycling of the catalysts [37–39]. An aluminum-based Metal-Organic Framework (Al-MOF) has been reported to be simple and economical to synthesize while possessing high thermal stability and large pore size [40,41]. It also provides highly electrophilic sites to support the metals at secondary building units (SBUs). Recently, one of these Al-MOFs called DUT-5 (Al(OH)(BPDC); BPDC = Biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate) has been considered for CO2 uptake [40]. With incorporated metal hydrides such as Ni(II) hydride and Co(II) hydride on its framework, it can serve as efficient catalysts especially for the deoxygenation of aromatic and aliphatic ketones, aldehydes, and secondary alcohols under mind condition [42]. It would, therefore, not be unexpected that the metal hydride-containing DUT-5 MOFs is also able to activate the carbonyl group of CO2 and catalyze the hydrogenation reaction. To the best of our knowledge, this has not yet been investigated, however. In this work, we investigate the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid on Al-MOF DUT-5 node support transition metals hydride (MH-DUT-5; M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) by means of computational methods. The methods, especially density functional theory (DFT) calculations are regarded as a powerful tool to provide insight into the properties of MOFs and also into the molecular details of the reaction mechanism of MOF catalysts [43–51]. We use the M06-L density functional to investigate the structures of adsorption complexes, transition states and products, as well as reaction mechanisms, energy profiles and barrier heights. 2 Computational details Fig. 1 shows the cluster model of DUT-5 employed in this work. It consists of four aluminum oxide units in which linkers are replaced by nine formic groups. The metal(II) hydrides are exchanged on the Brønsted site of DUT-5 to yield MH-DUT-5 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu). Previous works indicated that this model is well-suited to cover the major aspects of the MOF and also can mimic the active site of the DUT-5 MOF [41]. The structures of all species along the reaction coordinates, including reactants, intermediates, products, and transition states, were optimized with the M06-L density functional [52] as implemented in Gaussian 16 [53]. This functional is recommended for transition metals and inorganic and organometallic systems [54] and previous studies confirm its usability for investigating interactions and reaction mechanisms on metals-organic framework materials [42–48,55–57,46,58,59]. Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu atoms are described by the Stuttgart-Dresden pseudopotential with a double-ζ basis set [60], while for the other elements, the def2-SVP basis set was used. To include van der Waals interactions, we performed single point calculations with the D3 version of Grimme's correction [61]. Partial charges and orbital energies were determined by the natural bond orbital (NBO) method [62]. Frequency calculations were performed at the same level of theory to identify the nature of all the stationary points and to obtain thermodynamic properties of the system. The adsorption energies without thermal corrections calculated with both methods are very close to each other (−11.8 vs −11.2 kcal/mol for M06-L and DLPNO-CCSD(T), respectively), giving credentials for using the M06-L functional in the present study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures and reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid We first discuss the mechanisms of the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid on NiH-DUT-5. The NiH-DUT-5 is chosen because it is known to be an efficient catalysts for several of the reactions mentioned above. We investigate two possible mechanisms, Eley-Rideal (ER) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), using the model described above. The reaction pathways of both mechanisms is proposed to proceed in two steps. In both of them CO2 is hydrogenated, leading to a formate intermediate. Further hydrogenation results in formation of the formic acid product. The ER mechanism starts with CO2 adsorption while co-adsorption CO2 and H2 molecules is the initial step of the LH mechanism as shown in Fig. 2 . Gibbs free energy profile of the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid on NiH-DUT-5 is shown in Fig. 3 . In the ER mechanism the reaction proceeds by hydrogenation of CO2 to the formation of the formate intermediate which then is further hydrogenated to formic acid. CO2 binds on the Ni site by its O lone pair electron (Ads) with the O⋯Ni of 2.34 Å. The CO2 linear structure is distorted from its isolate molecule by reducing the angle of O1-C-O2 to be 174.2° due to the induction of such lone pair interaction. The O1-C bond is lengthened to be 1.17 Å, while the C-O2 bond length decreases from 1.17 to 1.16 Å. The stretching mode of the adsorbed CO2 is slight red-shifted to 2504.5 cm−1 while the bending mode is blue-shifted to 658.1 cm−1 The corresponding frequencies for gas phase CO2 are 2498.7 cm−1 for stretching and 659.4 cm−1 for bending. The changes of structural parameters and vibrations are comparable with previous computational studies of CO2 adsorption on various porous materials like MOFs and zeolites [64,65]. The NPA charge analysis shows some transfer electron of electron density from CO2 to the MOF (0.052e). In line with these small geometrical and vibrational effects, the adsorption free energy of CO2 is −1.1 kcal/mol. The adsorbed CO2 is first hydrogenated at its carbon atom via the transition state (TS1) in which the hydrogen atom on the Ni site transfers to the C1 carbon atom of CO2 to form a formate (HCOO–) intermediate where the Ni-H bond distance is lengthened to 1.61 Å, while the C⋅⋅⋅H distance is shortened to 1.86 Å, indicating bond formation. The normal mode analysis shows a single imaginary frequency of 451.4i cm−1 which is associated with the breaking of the Ni–H bond and the movement of H to the C atom. The activation energy for this step is 8.5 kcal/mol (cf. Fig. 2). The transition state then proceeds to the formate intermediate (Int_1) on the Ni site. It is adsorbed a bi-dentate structure with two oxygen atoms bound to the Ni center with a complexation energy of −19.4 kcal/mol. The O1–Ni and O2–Ni distances are 2.09 and 2.05 Å. This formate intermediate is a key species in the CO2 conversion reaction on various catalysts such as MOFs, zeolites and metals [64–66]. It was also observed as a bi-dentate species on Cu(111) [67,68]. By diffusion, a H2 molecule adsorbs adjacent to the formate intermediate, enabling the formation of the CO2-formate complex (Int_2) with the complexation energy of −14.2 kcal/mol. The formate is hydrogenated to form the formic acid via the hydrogenation transition state (TS2). The H1-H2 bond breaks and H1 and H2 are transferred to the O1 oxygen of formate and the Ni atom respectively. The H1-H2 bond is lengthened from 0.76 to 1.23 Å while the H1⋯Ni distance is shortened to 1.64 Å. The single imaginary frequency of transition state at 540.8i cm−1 corresponds to the simultaneous H1-H2 bond breaking and the formation of the H1–O1 and H2–Ni bonds. The activation energy for this step is 15.1 kcal/mol. Finally, the formic acid product (Prod) is produced and adsorbed on the active site of NiH-DUT-5 with an adsorption energy of −6.7 kcal/mol. It can desorb to regenerate the active site of catalysts with the desorption energy of 21.5 kcal/mol. We now compare the reaction coordinate of the LH mechanism with the ER mechanism discussed above. The LH mechanism begins with the co-adsorption of CO2 and H2 on the NiH active site. The corresponding O⋯Ni and C1⋯H1 distances are 2.34 and 3.44 Å, respectively and the co-adsorption energy is 3.5 kcal/mol, with respect to the isolate molecules. The co-adsorbed molecules react via a transition state in which the H-H bond of H2 is broken and H1 and H2 are simultaneously transferred to the C of CO2 and the H of NiH, respectively, as shown in Fig. 3. The H1-H2 bond lengths increases from 0.76 Å to 0.89 Å, while the H2⋅⋅⋅H distance and the C⋅⋅⋅H1 decrease, the imaginary frequency in this transition state is 638.8i cm−1 and its energy is 27.4 kcal/mol. The formate intermediate is then formed by adsorbing on the NiH site close to the generated H2 molecule with a bi-dentate structure with a complexation energy is of −14.2 kcal/mol. In the second half of the process, the formate hydrogenated in the same manner as in the ER mechanism. As shown in Fig. 3, the activation barrier for the formate formation via the LH mechanism is more than three times higher than via the ER mechanism and the latter is clearly preferred. We also performed the ER reaction calculations on an extended NiH-DUT-5 cluster model in which four organic linkers are included as shown in Fig. S1 to study size effects of the NiH-DUT-5 framework beyond our standard cluster model. The relative energies involved in the reaction are summarized in Table S1. It was found that the activation free energies are almost unaffected by the confinement in the NiH-DUT-5 framework. Therefore, we regard the DUT-5 cluster model used in this work to be sufficient to analyze the adsorption hydrogenation reaction. 3.2 Effect of supported DUT-5 node To reveal the influence of the support material, the ER mechanism without the DUT-5 node is investigated. We use Ni-H with a hydroxide group to keep the Ni charge state as shown in Fig. S2. Fig. 4 shows the relative energies along the reaction coordinate. All adsorbed intermediates and transition states are less stable than with the DUT-5 framework. The first CO2 hydrogenation step requires an activation energy of 14.4 kcal/mol, which is higher than the one with the DUT-5 support (8.5 kcal/mol). The reason is that support increases the electron density on the NiH site, leading to its increased nucleophilicity, thus better activating of CO2 for the hydrogenation step. However, the barrier for the second step, the formation of formic acid, is 14.4 kcal/mol without the DUT-5 framework while with it 15.1 kcal/mol were calculated. It is due to more stability of the formate intermediate in the MOFs system. Thus, DUT-5 acts as a reservoir of electron density and not only as a geometrical means to keep the metal sites in place. 3.3 Effect of the metal active site We study the hydrogenation of CO2 while varying the metal M = Mn, Fe, Co, and Cu, in addition to the Ni which has been discussed above. Because the hydrogenation of CO2 has been found to proceed via the ER mechanism, we stay with this mechanism for the reactions on the MH-DUT-5 MOFs. The relative energies are tabulated in Table 1 and the corresponding optimized structures with the key bond lengths for the reaction on MH-DUT-5 are presented in Figs. S3-S6 of the supporting information. All adsorption and transition states are found to be similar than for NiH-DUT-5 which has been discussed above. The free energies of activation for the formate intermediate formation step, relative to the energies of the isolated molecules, increase as follows: NiH-DUT-5 (8.5 kcal/mol) < MnH-DUT-5 (10.6 kcal/mol) < FeH-DUT-5 (11.6 kcal/mol) < CuH-DUT-5 (15.8 kcal/mol) < CoH-DUT-5 (16.8 kcal/mol), as shown in Table 1. These energies are lower than those obtained for the formate formation on Lewis acidic zeolites [65] and are in the range of the ones found for metal surfaces and metal supported carbon materials [66,69–73]. For NiH-DUT-5, the barrier is slightly lower than the one for CO2 reduction in the corresponding step on a Ni(111) surface [66]. For CuH-DUT-5, it is slightly higher than the one on UIO-68-supported NHC-Cu(I)-H [73] but still lower than on the one obtained from single Cu atoms supported carbon materials [70,71] and also lower than the one found for alkoxide-functionalized MOF-5 [64]. The formation free energies for the formate intermediate adsorbed on the metal site (relative to isolated molecule) range from −5.6 (CuH-DUT-5) to −23.0 kcal/mol (MnH-DUT-5). This intermediate is observed as a key intermediate because it is the most stable species of all studied here as can be seen from Table 1. For the formic acid formation step in which the co-adsorbed H2 molecule reacts with the formate on the active site of the MH-DUT-5, NiH-DUT-5 still shows the lowest Gibbs free energy of activation (15.1 kcal/mol), while CoH-DUT-5 shows the highest one (25.8 kcal/mol). The barriers are in the order of NiH-DUT-5 < FeH-DUT-5 < MnH-DUT-5 < CuH-DUT-5 < CoH-DUT-5. The energies of adsorption of formic acid on the active sites are in range of 2.5 to −6.7 kcal/mol. In Fig. 5 the activation energies for the formation of the intermediate and the ones for formation of the product are compared for all systems. One sees that the rate-determining step of the reaction is always the latter, the hydrogenation of formate to formic acid that involve H2 dissociation. This order was also previously found for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid on UIO-68-supported NHC-Cu(I)-H [73] and for Ir single-atom catalyst supported on porous organic polymer [74]. One also sees that NiH-DUT-5 requires the smallest activation free energy (15.1 kcal/mol) compared to the other metals. Rate constants for the rate-determining step can be calculated by classical TST according to Eq. (4): (4) k = k B T h e x p ( − Δ G # R T ) where k is the rate constant, kB is Boltzmann's constant, h is Planck's constant, T is the temperature, R is the universal gas constant, and ΔG # is the rate-determining step free energy barrier. The rate constants were derived for a reaction temperature of 298.15 K and are shown in Table 2 . Their order is obviously reverse to the order of the activation energies, NiH-DUT-5 > FeH-DUT-5 > MnH-DUT-5 > CuH-DUT-5 > CoH-DUT-5. One can summarize that amongst the five metals, NiH-DUT-5 holds most promise as a catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions We studied the reaction mechanism of the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid on aluminum‐based metal‐organic framework support metal(II)-hydride in detail using DFT calculations. The reaction is found to proceed via an ER mechanism involving two steps, the first one leading to a formate intermediate which in turn is hydrogenated to formic acid. NiH-DUT-5 is found to have the lowest barriers for the first and second step (8.5 and 15.1 kcal/mol, respectively). The hydrogenation of CO2 to formate via the LH mechanism would require 27.4 kcal/mol, three times more than with the ER mechanism. The supported DUT-5 stabilizes almost all species formed along the reaction coordinates, but especially the transition states. All five metals hydride supported DUT-5 on the reaction were investigated. In all systems the rate determining steps is the hydrogenation of formate to formic acid. The free energies of activation for the rate determining steps increase as follows: NiH-DUT-5 (15.1 kcal/mol) < FeH-DUT-5 (19.3 kcal/mol) < MnH-DUT-5 (20.5 kcal/mol) < CuH-DUT-5 (21.5 kcal/mol) < CoH-DUT-5 (25.8 kcal/mol). Corresponding rate constants have also been calculated. The catalyst NiH-DUT-5 is predicted to be the most active one. CRediT authorship contribution statement Krongkwan Nilwanna: Investigation. coredata.dc:description: Conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to value-added chemicals is achieving increased attention from an environmental and industrial perspective because it could reduce the dependency on petroleum as raw material and also its net emission into the atmosphere. We present mechanisms for the CO2 hydrogenation on the aluminum-based metal-organic framework DUT-5 support transition metal(II)-hydride in a detailed using density functional (DFT) calculations. Two different pathways, namely, Eley-Rideal (ER) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanisms are described. The ER mechanism requires activation barriers of 8.5 and 15.1 kcal/mol for the formation of formate and of formic acid steps, respectively. The first barrier is three times lower than in the LH mechanism (27.4 kcal/mol), thus favouring the ER mechanism. Supported DUT-5 MOFs are also found to have a stabilizing effect on the intermediates and transition states formed along the reaction coordinate. Finally, we screen the catalytic activities of different metals substituted into MH-DUT-5 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) MOFs for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid. It is found that NiH-DUT-5 exhibits the highest catalytic activity, based on its barriers.
